title: 113_hr5661
content: The Act may be cited as the "Keep Our Promise to America's Children and Teachers Act" or the "Keep Our PACT Act". The Congress acknowledges the importance of children and education, emphasizing the need for high-quality education for all students. Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act aims to address educational inequity, while the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act ensures quality education for children with disabilities. Congress is committed to providing adequate funding for students with disabilities. Funding is appropriated from the Treasury for fiscal years 2015 and 2016 for programs under part A of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The amounts are based on the authorized funding levels for those years. For fiscal years 2017 and 2018, funding amounts are determined based on the appropriations for programs under part A of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, with a minimum threshold set at $19,049,895,000 or the full authorized amount, whichever is higher. For fiscal years 2019 and 2020, funding amounts are determined based on the appropriations for programs under part A of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, with a minimum threshold set at $25,227,912,000 for 2019 and $29,031,913,000 for 2020, or the full authorized amount, whichever is higher. For fiscal years 2021 and 2022, funding amounts are determined based on the appropriations for programs under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, with a minimum threshold set at $33,409,503,000 for 2021 and $38,447,168,000 for 2022, or the full authorized amount, whichever is higher. For fiscal years 2021 and 2022, funding amounts are determined based on the appropriations for programs under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, with a minimum threshold set at $33,409,503,000 for 2021 and $38,447,168,000 for 2022, or the full authorized amount, whichever is higher. For fiscal years 2023 and 2024, the funding amounts are calculated as the difference between the amount appropriated for fiscal year 2015 for these programs and either $44,244,442,000 or $50,915,859,000, whichever is higher for 2023, and for 2024, respectively. For fiscal year 2024, the funding amount will be the difference between the appropriated amount for programs under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 for 2015 and either $58,593,228,000 or the full authorized amount for that year, whichever is higher. SEC. 4. MANDATORY FUNDING OF THE INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES EDUCATION ACT. Section 611(i) of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is amended to authorize funding for fiscal year 2015, with specific amounts allocated for different purposes. For fiscal years 2016 and 2017, specific amounts are appropriated for various purposes, with funds becoming available on specific dates and remaining available for a set period. For fiscal years 2018 and 2019, specific amounts are appropriated, with funds becoming available on specific dates and remaining available for a set period. For fiscal year 2019, $9.4 billion or 9.4% of the determined amount is available from July 1, 2019, to September 30, 2020. For fiscal year 2020, $23.2 billion or 27.2% of the determined amount is available, with $11.8 billion or 11.9% becoming available from July 1, 2020, to September 30, 2021. Additionally, $26.2 billion or 30% of the amount is allocated. For fiscal year 2021, $26.2 billion or 30% of the determined amount is allocated, with $14.7 billion or 14.7% appropriated for the same year. For fiscal year 2022, $29.4 billion or 33% is allocated, with $17.9 billion or 17.7% appropriated. For fiscal year 2022, $33,096,577,000 or 36.3% of the determined amount is allocated, with $21,623,729,000 or 21% appropriated. For fiscal year 2023, $37,231,164,000 or 40% is allocated for each subsequent fiscal year. For fiscal year 2024 and beyond, $37,231,164,000 or 40% of the determined amount is appropriated, whichever is greater. The funds will be available for obligation from July 1, 2024, through September 30, 2025, and for each subsequent fiscal year from July 1 to September 30 of the following year. The amount determined under this paragraph is based on the total number of children with disabilities who received special education services in the previous school year and the average per-pupil expenditure in public schools. The amount determined is based on the total number of children with disabilities who received special education services in the previous school year and the average per-pupil expenditure in public schools. SEC. 5. OFFSET. The amounts appropriated by this Act and the amendments made by this Act shall be expended consistent with pay-as-you-go requirements.
